When a small group of living things (a small population) is separated from the main population from which it originated (for example, if it moves over a mountain range or a river, or if it moves to a new island so that it cannot easily return), it often finds itself in a different environment from the one it was in before.
This new environment has different resources and competitors, so the new population will need new characteristics or adaptations to be a powerful competitor compared to what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all, it still needs the same adaptations.
Over time, as the new population adapts to its new environment, it begins to look less and less like the other population.
Finally, after thousands or even millions of years, the two populations will look so different that they will no longer be considered to belong to the same species.
We call this process "speciation", which simply means the formation of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and an important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, ranging from technological push or technological imperative to a strict sense in which the destiny of humanity is dictated by an underlying logic linked to scientific laws and their manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism agree on two general ideas: the development of technology itself transcends cultural and political influences, and technology has an impact on societies conditioned intrinsically rather than socially.
For example, one could say that the automobile necessarily leads to the development of roads.
However, a national road network is not economically viable for a handful of cars, so new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of owning a car.
Massive car ownership also leads to a higher incidence of accidents on the roads, which leads to the invention of new techniques in the field of health care to treat the resulting injuries.

Wagonways were built in England as early as the 16th century.

Although the wagon ways were simply made up of parallel wooden planks, they allowed the horses that pulled them to reach greater speeds and pull heavier loads than on the slightly more accident-prone roads of the day.
Crossings were introduced early on to keep the tracks in place. However, it was soon realized that the tracks would be more effective if they were equipped with a strip of iron on top.
This has become a common practice, but iron has caused more wear on the wooden wheels of the wagons.
Finally, wooden wheels were replaced by iron wheels. In 1767, the first iron rails appeared.

After its adoption by Congress on July 4, a handwritten manuscript signed by the President of Congress John Hancock and Secretary Charles Thomson was then sent to a few streets away, at the printing house of John Dunlap.
During the night, between 150 and 200 copies were made, now known as the "Dunlap Broadsides".
The first public reading of the document was made by John Nixon in Independence Hall on July 8.
One of them was sent to George Washington on July 6, who read it to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy arrived in London on August 10.
The 25 Dunlap copies that we know of are the oldest copies of the document. The original manuscript has not survived.

Traffic flow is the study of the movements of drivers and individual vehicles between two points, and the interactions they have with each other.

Fortunately, drivers tend to act in a reasonable range; thus, traffic flows tend to have a reasonable coherence and can be represented mathematically in an approximate manner.
To better represent the flow of traffic, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) bandwidth, (2) density, and (3) speed.
These relationships help with planning, design and operation of road facilities.

The modern city of Casablanca was founded by Berber fishermen in the 10th century BCE, and was used by the Phoenicians, the Romans, and the Merinides as a strategic port called Anfa.
The Portuguese, who had destroyed it and rebuilt it and called it Casa Branca, finally abandoned it in 1755 after an earthquake.
The Moroccan sultan rebuilt the city under the name Daru l-Badya and it was renamed Casablanca by the Spanish merchants who established trading posts there.
Casablanca is one of the least interesting places in all of Morocco for shopping.

Around the old medina, it's easy to find places where you can buy traditional Moroccan products, such as tagines, pottery, leather goods, hookahs and all sorts of souvenirs, but that's all for tourists.
Goma is a tourist town in the extreme east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, near Rwanda.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in northeastern South Africa and borders the Mozambique border to the east, the Zimbabwe border to the north and the Crocodile River forms the southern border.

It is one of the best known theme parks in South Africa and considered the jewel in the crown of South African National Parks (SANParks).
As with all South African national parks, there are daily entrance and conservation fees for the park.

The Sundarbans are the largest coastal mangrove forest in the world, stretching 80 km (50 miles) from the coast to the hinterland of Bangladesh and India.
The Sundarbans have been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest located on Indian territory is called the Sundarbans National Park.
Forests, however, are not composed solely of mangrove swamps: they also contain some of the last remnants of the majestic jungles that once covered the Gangetic Plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which about a third is covered by water/marshland.
Sundarbans is a natural reserve since 1966, you can find there about 400 Bengal tigers and 30,000 spotted deer.

The Oyapock Bridge is a suspension bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the towns of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges-de-l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
The two towers rise to a height of 83 m; it is 378 m long and has two lanes 3.5 m wide.
The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The structure was completed in August 2011, but was not opened to traffic until March 2017.
The bridge should be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs posts should be completed.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Islands pound (FKP) whose value is equivalent to a pound sterling (GBP).

The stirrups are foot supports for the rider, which hang on either side of the saddle.
They offer greater stability to the user, but they can pose a safety problem: in fact, the user's feet can get stuck in them.
If a rider is thrown from a horse, but has a foot caught in the stirrup, he could be dragged if the horse runs away. To minimize this risk, a number of safety measures can be taken.
First of all, most riders wear riding boots with a heel and a smooth and narrow sole.
Then, some saddles, especially English ones, have safety bars that allow a stirrup to fall off the saddle if it is pulled backwards by a rider who falls.

Violent weather is the generic term for any meteorological phenomenon that can cause damage, serious social disruption or loss of human life.

Violent winds, hail, excessive rainfall and fires are forms and effects of violent weather, just as thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, and typhoons.
Extreme meteorological phenomena, regional and seasonal, include cold-weather storms, snowstorms with strong winds, and sandstorms or dust storms.

Japanese work culture is more hierarchical and formal than that to which Westerners may be accustomed.
